english_translation: Muhammad ibn Umar informed us. He said: Ibrahim ibn Muhammad ibn Shurahbil al-Abdari narrated to us, from Musab ibn Muhammad ibn Shurahbil meaning ibn Hasanah. He said: Utbah ibn Ghazwan had attended with Sa'd ibn Abi Waqqas when the non-Arabs were defeated. Then Umar ibn al-Khattab wrote to Sa'd ibn Abi Waqqas: 'That he should establish his headquarters at Kufa, and that he send Utbah ibn Ghazwan to the land of India, for he has a rank in Islam, and witnessed Badr, and I hope his reward will be for the Muslims. And Basra was called at that time the land of India. So he should settle it, and take it as a headquarters for the Muslims, and not let there be a sea between me and them.' So Sa'd ibn Abi Waqqas called upon Utbah ibn Ghazwan and informed him of the letter of Umar, and he agreed, and departed from Kufa with eight hundred men. They journeyed until they settled in Basra. Basra was indeed named Basra because there were black stones in it. When Utbah ibn Ghazwan settled it, he established his headquarters and settled it, and the Muslims pitched their tents and camps. Utbah ibn Ghazwan pitched a tent for himself from garments. Then Umar ibn al-Khattab sent men, and when they became many, a group among them built seven fortified quarters from mud brick in it. In al-Khurayba were two, in al-Zabuqa was one, in Bani Tamim were two, in al-Azd were two. Then Utbah went forth to the Furat of Basra and conquered it, then returned to Basra. The people of Basra used to raid the mountains of Persia neighboring them. Then a letter from Umar ibn al-Khattab came to Utbah ibn Ghazwan that: settle it with the Muslims, so they may be there, and let them raid their enemy from near.

english_translation: Utbah preached to the people, and it was the first sermon he delivered in Basra. He said: 'All praise is due to Allah, I praise Him and seek His assistance, I believe in Him and rely upon Him, I bear witness that there is no god but Allah, and that Muhammad is His servant and Messenger. As for what follows: O people, verily this world has departed with haste and has announced farewell to its inhabitants. Nothing remains of it except a remnant like the remainder in a vessel. Indeed, you will inevitably leave it, so leave it with the best you have at hand. Verily, it is a marvel that a mighty stone is cast from the brink of Hell and falls for seventy years until it reaches its bottom, by Allah it will be filled. And verily, it is a marvel that Paradise has seven gates, the width between the sides of one gate is a journey of fifty years. By Allah, there shall come upon them a time when it is so crowded with throngs. And I have seen myself with the Messenger of Allah ﷺ as seventh of seven people, we had no food except the leaves of al-Bishaam and the thorns of al-Qatad until our mouths became sore from them. And I once picked up a garment and split it between myself and Sa'd ibn Abi Waqqas. And I have seen us afterward, we seven of the group, none of us except that he became an emir over a region of the regions. And indeed, there was no prophethood except that kingship succeeded it. So I seek refuge with Allah that that time should come to us in which the ruler becomes a king. And I seek refuge with Allah that I should be great in my own estimation and small in the estimation of people. You shall try the emirs after us and will try them, so you will know and deny.' So while Utbah was in his sermon, a man from Thaqif approached with a letter from Umar to Utbah ibn Ghazwan in which it said: As for what follows: Abu Abdullah al-Thaqafi mentioned to me that he had acquired horses in Basra when no one else was acquiring them. So when this letter of mine reaches you, treat Abu Abdullah well and help him in what he has asked your assistance for. Abu Abdullah was the first to tether a horse in Basra and took it for himself. Then it said: Utbah marched to Maysan and Ubziqabad and conquered them. The Marzuban, lord of the fortresses, came out against him with a large force and fought them. Allah defeated the Marzuban. The Marzuban sought reconciliation, so he struck his neck and took his robe and belt in which were gold and jewels. He sent that to Umar ibn al-Khattab. When the spoils of the Marzuban reached Medina, the people asked the messenger about the condition of the people. The arriving messenger said: O gathering of Muslims, why do you ask? By Allah, I left the people gathering gold and silver. The people became eager. Umar then began to send men to him in groups of one hundred and fifty and the like as reinforcement to Utbah in Basra.

english_translation: Sa'd used to write to Utbah while he was his deputy. Utbah found displeasure in this, so he sought permission from Umar to come to him, and he gave him permission. He appointed al-Mughira ibn Shu'bah as deputy over Basra. Utbah came to Umar and complained to him about Sa'd's dominance over him. Umar was silent about it. Utbah repeated this matter several times. When Utbah pressed Umar, he said: What is against you, O Utbah, that you acknowledge the authority of a man from Quraysh who has companionship with the Messenger of Allah ﷺ and nobility? Utbah said to him: Am I not from Quraysh? The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: The ally of the people is from them. And I have ancient companionship with the Messenger of Allah ﷺ that is not denied and not disputed. Umar said: That virtue of yours is not denied. Utbah said: Now that the matter has come to this, by Allah I will not return to it ever. Umar insisted on returning him to it, and he returned. But Utbah died on the way. His rule over Basra lasted six months. A stomach illness afflicted him and he died at the mine of Bani Sulaim. Suwaid, his slave, brought his possessions and inheritance to Umar ibn al-Khattab. This was in the year seventeen of the Hijra. Utbah ibn Ghazwan was fifty-seven years old when he died.

english_translation: He had the kunya Abu Abdullah. He embraced Islam when the Prophet ﷺ passed by him until emigration, and remained in his people's territory so he did not witness Badr. Then he emigrated to Medina and was continuously with the Messenger of Allah ﷺ and accompanied him in his battles thereafter until the Prophet ﷺ passed away. When Basra was conquered and settled, he moved to it and marked out a plot for himself and built a house there. Then he left from it as a fighter to Khurasan during the caliphate of Uthman ibn Affan, and continued there until he died in Merv during the caliphate of Yazid ibn Mu'awiyah. His descendants remained there, and some people came with his descendants and settled in Baghdad and died there.

And some said: Natlah ibn Ubaid ibn al-Harith ibn Jiyal ibn Rabi'ah ibn Du'bal ibn Anas ibn Khuzaimah ibn Malik ibn Salamah ibn Aslam ibn Afsaa. He said: Abu Barzah embraced Islam early and witnessed with the Messenger of Allah ﷺ the conquest of Makkah. He did not cease to fight with the Messenger of Allah ﷺ until the Messenger of Allah ﷺ died. Then he moved to Basra and settled there when the Muslims settled there. He built a house there and for him there is in it a remaining legacy and descendants. Then he fought in Khurasan and died in Merv.

english_translation: Rauh ibn Ubadah informed us. He said: Shu'bah narrated to us. He said: Mufaddal ibn Fadala, a man from Quraysh, narrated to us. From Abu Rajaa al-Utaridi. He said: Imran ibn al-Husayn came out to us wearing a silk wrap, which we had never seen him wearing before or after. He said: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: 'Indeed, when Allah bestows a blessing upon a slave, He loves to see the traces of His blessing upon His slave.' And also: Affan ibn Muslim and al-Mu'alla ibn Asad informed us. They said: Abd al-Rahman ibn al-Urayyah narrated to us. He said: Abu Imran al-Jawni narrated to us: That he 'saw upon Imran ibn Husayn a silk wrap.' And also: Muhammad ibn Ubaid al-Tanaafisi informed us. He said: Al-A'mash narrated to us. From Hilal ibn Yasaf. He said: 'I came to Basra and entered the mosque. I found an old man with white hair and beard, leaning against a pillar in a circle teaching people. I asked: Who is this? They said: Imran ibn al-Husayn.'

english_translation: Wahb ibn Jarir informed us. He said: My father narrated to us. He said: I heard Humaid ibn Hilal while he was narrating from Mutatrif. He said: I said to Imran ibn Husayn: What prevents me from visiting you except what I see of your condition (illness). He said: 'Then do not do that, for what is beloved to Allah is beloved to me.' And also: Hafs ibn Umar al-Hawdi informed us. He said: Yazid ibn Ibrahim narrated to us. He said: I heard Muhammad, meaning Ibn Sireen, saying: 'The stomach of Imran ibn Husayn was diseased for thirty years. Throughout that time, cauterization was presented to him, but he refused to be cauterized, until two years before his death, he consented to cauterization.'

english_translation: Wahb ibn Jarir ibn Hazim informed us. He said: My father narrated to us. He said: I heard Humaid ibn Hilal narrating from Mutatrif. He said: Imran ibn Husayn said to me: 'Are you aware that angels used to greet me, but when I was cauterized, the greeting ceased?' I said: 'Did the greeting come to you from above your head or from below your feet?' He said: 'No, but from above my head.' I said: 'I do not think he will die until that returns to him.' Later he said to me: 'Are you aware that the greeting has returned to me?' Then not long after that he died.

He said: 'I made a vow that if I recovered from this ailment, I would display my acts of worship.'

He said: I heard al-A'mash narrating from Hilal ibn Yasaf. From Mutatrif. He said: We were with Imran ibn al-Husayn sitting in the mosque, and we would not leave him except he would teach us something good and kind. One day he said: 'Today my stomach seized me so violently that I cannot teach. I had hoped not to see this day. By Allah, I have not taken anything of the dunya (worldly life), yet it does not exempt me from its trial.'
